chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Saint Martin is known to be a helper.

At that time, all the funds he had brought with him to build the monastery workshop were used up. These events took place around the feast day of Saint Martin. Our tradition is to celebrate it over eight days.

After finishing the morning celebration on the eighth day, and before dawn, everyone returned to their beds, more to rest than to sleep. Our father mentioned that an elderly woman had a vision revealed to her.

She saw a venerable man with white hair, dressed in a splendid robe, wearing a rain cloak, and carrying a bishop's staff. He approached and began to inspect the monastery's structure. When asked who he was and why he was looking around, he replied, "I am the one whose feast the brothers celebrate on the eighth day; I have come to visit them. Tell them not to lose heart, but to continue the work they have started."

He also mentioned that all the funds he had brought were exhausted. And he said, "Do not be afraid. Look, I am now coming from Rome and heading to Tours. I will travel through Gaul and Aquitaine, and from these regions, I will send them such support that they will have plenty now, and it will last long after."

The brothers, happy and reassured by the promise of such a great man, began to give thanks to God with joy.

As for who this person was, I do not dare to declare, because it was our father's way to never attribute anything directly to himself. But if he saw something great or small, he would describe it like this. One of our brothers, or an elderly woman, saw this or that.

Every time he told me this, he also mentioned that within a few days after this revelation, more than three thousand gold coins were brought from the borders of Gaul.

S. Martinum adjutorem experitur. 2. Per illud namque tempus defecit omnis sumptus,
quem secum detulerat in construenda monasterii
officina. Fiebant autem haec omnia circa
beati Martini natalitia. Est autem consuetudo nostra
octo dierum circulo celebrare eam. Peracta
itaque diei octavi celebritate matutina, et necdum

strata, requietionis potius quam dormitationis gratia:
ferebatque pater noster cuidam vetulae personae
talem revelatam fuisse visionem. Aspiciebat, et
ecce vir venerabilis canitie decoratus, stolaque

qui proprius accedens, structuram ejus monasterii

 visitare eos veni. Dicito illis ne deficiant, sed in

illa, quia defecisset omnis sumptus quem secum detulerat. Ac ille: Ne timeant, inquit. Ecce nunc a Roma
venio et Turoniam  vado. Iter autem meum per Gutiam
Aquitaniamque faciam, et ex his partibus tantum
eis pensum mandabo, ut eis hoc tempore affluenter

et de tanti viri promissione securi, omni cum hilaritate
Deo gratias coeperunt agere. Cujus autem
haec persona fuerit, profiteri non audeo, quia patris

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He used to tell me such great and wonderful stories about what happened at the monastery of Saint Benedict, known as Fleury, and also at Cluny. If I dared to write it all out in detail, the book would become too long for the writer to handle.

As we more clearly narrate the very faithful promise of blessed Martin being fulfilled, I'm suddenly reminded of the significant aid from wild animals.

This might make some readers laugh, but since we have become a spectacle to angels and humans, those who refuse to imitate us, or cannot, may at least be moved by us. Seeing us progress from good to better things, and finally leaving behind a sorrowful life, may they follow with all joy into eternal happiness.

Tanta namque et talia sub
 tali specie mihi narrare solitus erat, quae apud coenobium
sancti Benedicti, quod dicitur Floriacum,
gesta fuerunt, simili modo et apud Cluniacum;
quae si auderem ad liquidum exarare, libelli modus
ultra dictatoris se facultatulam extenderet. Sed
ecce dum beati Martini fidelissimam promissionem
enucleatius adimpletam narramus, subito ad mentem
recurrit ferarum bestiarum non perparvum adminiculum. Quod fortassis descriptum quibusdam
legentibus incutiet risum: sed quia spectaculum
facti sumus angelis et hominibus, hi qui nos imitari
dedignantur, aut nequeunt, habeant de nobis saltim
excussum, videntes nos proficere a bonis in melioribus:
ac tandem relinquentes lugubrem vitam,
omni cum exsultatione sequantur in aeterna gaudia.
